comments:
Hi - 

I unpacked Eclipse.  Then fired off the executable and got this error written 
to the log file ???  Any ideas.

Thnaks

!SESSION ----------------------------------------------------------------------


!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.launcher 4 0 Mar 26, 2003 17:16:33.988
!MESSAGE Exception launching the Eclipse Platform:
!STACK
java.lang.RuntimeException: Could not find bootstrap code. Check location of 
boot plug-in or specify -boot.
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.searchForBoot(Main.java:424)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.getBootPath(Main.java:394)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:237)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:703)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:539)

Is there anything special about the path where eclipse is installed?  I'm
thinking of strange characters such as "!@#$%^&" or UNC paths.

This has been reported in the past but we have never been able to reproduce it.
 We should at least add more diagnostic information in the error log in this
case so we can debug it further.  

Darryl, if you try running again but add the "-debug" command line argument and
start with java.exe instead of javaw.exe, what do you see in the console view?

For example, run "eclipse.exe -vm d:\jre\bin\java.exe -debug"
got it sorted now.  Thanks

Can you give us a quick idea of what was wrong?  We get this same bug report
from time to time but don't know what's causing it.  This would help us save
people from grief if it happens again.
Closing this bug, but please let us know what the problem was if you can.

I've just hit this one also, and Rafael Chaves asked me to put the relevant info
here. I'm running Eclipse 2.1 on WinXP, installed in my c:\eclipse.org
directory. I also installed Java 1.3 along with IBM's Websphere Preview
Technologies. I'm running it by double-clicking a shortcut created by
alt-dragging eclipse.exe to my desktop, and I've not modified any of the
shortcut preferences.

I started hitting this problem after this sequence of events:
1) Install eclipse 2.1
2) Install Websphere stuff and Java
 -- everything worked at this point --
3) Mess up the eclipse directory structure by incorrectly unzipping examples
4) Attempt to fix (3) by uninstalling and re-installing eclipse.

Now I hit the error every time.

Michael, if you edit your eclipse.exe shortcut and add the "-debug" command line
parameter, what do you see in the console?  It should tell you where it's
looking for the bootstrapping code.  Your shortcut "Target" should look
something like this:

D:\eclipse\eclipse.exe -debug -vm d:\jre\bin\java.exe

This might help us figure out what went wrong.
Michael, could you comment on John's question above? Thanks.

I'm having trouble getting the info you want...

First off, let me apologize for the incorrect information in my previous update.
The directory where Eclipse.exe is located is c:\Program Files\eclipse.org. My
shortcut target doesn't contain a -vm switch, so I added your debug switch and
it looks like this:

"C:\Program Files\eclipse.org\eclipse.exe" -debug

Now when I double-click the shortcut, I got a DOS window that flashes some text
too quickly to read, and the same entry in the .log file.

I'm reopening this bug, because we should at least be giving a more informative
error message in this case.

Michael, can you try this:

- Open a Windows Command Prompt
- go to the eclipse install directory (cd "c:\Program Files\eclipse.org\eclipse")
- type the following:

java -cp startup.jar org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main -debug

This will run Eclipse in the same command shell, and you should be able to see
the error message correctly.

John, here's what it shows:

C:\Program Files\eclipse.org>java -cp startup.jar org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main
 -debug
Startup: unable to load configuration
java.io.FileNotFoundException: C:\Program Files\eclipse.org\.config\platform.cfg
 (The system cannot find the path specified)

C:\Program Files\eclipse.org>

By looking through our startup code, the only possiblity seems to be that the
boot plugin is indeed missing.  If you look in your install directory
"eclipse.org", you should see a jar called startup.jar, and a sub-directory
called "plugins".  This directory should contain a sub-directory called
"org.eclipse.core.boot_2.1.0".  Do you see this?  If not, you've really messed
up your install.

Ahh... I *had* messed up the install, but I still don't know how I did what I
did. What I've ended up with is c:\Program Files\eclipse.org containing
eclipse.exe, startup.jar, etc. I also have c:\Program Files\eclipse.org\eclipse,
which contains the same files... it's *this* directory that has the \plugins
subdirectory. The shortcut I had been using was to eclipse.exe in the
\eclipse.org directory; when I made a new one to
\eclipse.org\eclipse\eclipse.exe, everything works as advertised.

Go ahead and change the error message if you want to. I'm back in business and
grateful for your help. I'm available to test a fix, if you need me to. My own
two cents is that the message shouldn't refer to the -boot switch if it's
deprecated.

Old summary: Could not find bootstrap code

Need to change the error message to reference -configuration.

I had the same problem and the comments entered for this item helped me to 
identify the problem.  There were two things that I did wrong when I installed 
the Eclipse software:

1.  I copied the .ZIP file into the \Eclipse folder that I created.
    I should have extracted the files from the root folder on the drive
    (I'm using Windows 2000 Professional) and let WinZip create the 
    Eclipse folder and the sub-folders.
2.  I didn't have WinZip set up to use the folder names defined in the
    .ZIP file.  As a result, the sub-folders in the \Eclipse folder were
    not created.

Solution:
1.  Extract the files from the .ZIP file from the root folder and let
    the WinZip software create the Eclipse folder for you.
2.  Make sure that WinZip will use the folder names in the .ZIP file.
    When extracting, make sure that the "Use Folder Names" check box
    is checked.

hello,
i had the exact error.  

when i downloaded the file eclipse-SDK-2.1-win32.zip

steps in creating error:
1. create a directory c:\eclipse
2. extract files to that directory
3. start eclipse and get the bootstrap error -- eclipse will not start.

fixing the error.
1. remove the directory c:\eclipse
2. when extracting to c:\ check the option in winzip to use folder name
3. extract the file eclipse-SDK-2.1-win32.zip
4. i get the directory structure of:
     c:\eclipse
     c:\eclipse\features
     c:\eclipse\plugins
     c:\eclipse\readme
     c:\eclipse\workspace

eclipse comes up.

note: the directory plugins,features and 
 i had previously installed j2sdk1.4.1_01

Ed Chase

Same error, but here compiling from sources
(eclipse-sourceBuild-srcIncluded-3.0M2.zip) on Gentoo Linux x86 (Compaq Presario
2500).
Compiled with command
./build -os linux -ws gtk -arch x86

Compile log appended.

Then, to execute, I type 

gfv@isene eclipse $ cd result/eclipse/linux.gtk.x86/eclipse  
gfv@isene eclipse $ ./eclipse -vm /opt/blackdown-jdk-1.4.1/bin/java

Maybe I'm loosing something, but documentation seems to be a bit Windows-centric.

gfv@isene eclipse $ cat workspace/.metadata/.log

Warning. It's a bit long. Gzipped

I got this same error message, after reading your description, I realized I had 
unzipped with the
 "Used Folder Names" Checked Off.  This put everything in one directory.  I 
cleaned up the directory and started over with the this Checked On, Eclipse 
Launched with no trouble.

Well. In my case I cannot check or uncheck "Used Folder Names". I use Linux, 
and it seems that's Windows related (Maybe Winzip ???)

I've had this error when running from a network drive on windows for 
example //somecomputer/eclipse. I fixed it by mapping //somecomputer to a drive 
letter.

Ok, I had this error as well on a Windows XP system running on a campus 
network. The eclipse directory was located on another computer, i.e., 
\\somecomputer\eclipse\. The directory structure was *NOT* the problem in this 
case though it generates the same error, as many of the others that had this 
problem were stating. The problem, as noted by Peter Tiedmann was fixed by 
mapping the somecomputer to a local drive, i.e., Y:\eclipse. This solved it 
right away and up opened Eclipse. Why this is the case is beyond me, but it's 
a tricky little bug when you don't know what is going on.

Peter and Jess, the UNC path problem is bug 28656. This bug report is for
improving the error message when the user incorrectly installs the product.

these error messages have all be revamped in the new runtime.  you now get a 
report like...

Install location:
    file:d:/i0325/eclipse/
Configuration file:
    file:d:/i0325/eclipse/configuration/config.ini loaded
Configuration location:
    file:d:/i0325/eclipse/configuration/
Framework located:
    file:d:/i0325/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.osgi_3.0.0/
Framework classpath:
    file:d:/i0325/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.osgi_3.0.0/core.jar
    file:d:/i0325/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.osgi_3.0.0/console.jar
    file:d:/i0325/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.osgi_3.0.0/osgi.jar
    file:d:/i0325/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.osgi_3.0.0/resolver.jar
    file:d:/i0325/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.osgi_3.0.0/defaultAdaptor.jar
    file:d:/i0325/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.osgi_3.0.0/eclipseAdaptor.jar
Splash location:
    d:\i0325\eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.platform_3.0.0\splash.bmp
Debug-Options:
    file:D:/i0325/eclipse/.options

if you spec -debug on the command line

Since there are few hard rules about where these things should be it is hard to 
be too specific in the messages but the situation is improved.
